hook: Blockbuster’s biggest 1990s rival that vanished in the streaming era.
fate: Acquired by Movie Gallery in 2005; parent company liquidated in 2010, closing all Hollywood Video stores.
summary: **Hollywood Video** grew into the No. 2 U.S. video-rental chain through the 1990s, competing head-to-head with Blockbuster on big-box stores, new releases, and late-fee promos. After a 2005 acquisition by **Movie Gallery**, heavy debt, shrinking DVD rentals, and the rise of mail/streaming services pushed the business into bankruptcy. By **2010**, the parent liquidated and Hollywood Video stores closed nationwide. *Fun fact:* many locations housed an in-store game shop called **Game Crazy**, which ran trade-ins years before that model became mainstream.

timeline.text: Hollywood Video founded; rapid store expansion through the 1990s.
Peak footprint as Blockbuster’s main national rival; launches Game Crazy shop-in-shop.
Acquired by Movie Gallery, creating a combined national rental giant.
Movie Gallery files Chapter 11 amid industry decline; restructuring follows.
Movie Gallery files again and liquidates; all Hollywood Video stores close.
